answer_html: \(\displaystyle -\sqrt{5} < x_1 < q < x_2 < m < \sqrt{5}\) but in particular that means that q is in the interval (-,) and since it is rational, q is an element of the set M. But by construction, q < m which contradicts the assumption that m could be a lower bound of the set M. This means that such a number m cannot exist and hence the infimum of the set M has to be -.
hints_html: Recall that inf(M) denotes the infimum of the set M, that is the largest real number that is smaller than any element of the set M.
hints_latex:
Recall that inf(\emph{M}) denotes the
{\emph{infimum}} of the set
\emph{M}, that is the largest real number that is smaller than any
element of the set \emph{M}.
hints_raw: Recall that inf(''M'') denotes the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infimum ''infimum''] of the set ''M'', that is the largest real number that is smaller than any element of the set ''M''.
sols_html:
The condition

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x^2 < 5\end{aligned}\]

is equivalent to the conditions

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle - \sqrt{5} < x < \sqrt{5}\end{aligned}\]

This means, we can rewrite the set M as being

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle M = \mathbb{Q} \cap (-\sqrt{5},\sqrt{5})\end{aligned}\]

The infimum of a set being the largest real number that is smaller or equal to all the numbers of the set, it seems to be a good idea to think that - is a good candidate for the infimum of the set M.

Since - is clearly smaller than all the numbers of the set M, we only need to show that it is the largest real number with that property.

Assume that there is a number m with that property as well, that is strictly larger than -, that is

\[\begin{aligned} m \leq x \quad\text{for all } x \in M \quad\text{and}\quad m > -\sqrt{5}\end{aligned}\]

We’ll simply show that such a m cannot exist and hence - is the infimum of the set M.

Indeed, if m is strictly larger than - than it means that the interval

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-\sqrt{5} , m)\end{aligned}\]

is not empty. Since non-empty interval of real numbers contain infinitely many numbers, we can find two distinct numbers in that interval \(x_1\) and \(x_2\), that is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -\sqrt{5} < x_1 < x_2 < m\end{aligned}\]

Now a property of the rational numbers is that you can always find a rational number between any two distinct real numbers. That means there must exist a rational number q between \(x_1\) and \(x_2\), so we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -\sqrt{5} < x_1 < q < x_2 < m < \sqrt{5}\end{aligned}\]

but in particular that means that q is in the interval (-,) and since it is rational, q is an element of the set M. But by construction, q < m which contradicts the assumption that m could be a lower bound of the set M. This means that such a number m cannot exist and hence the infimum of the set M has to be -.
sols_raw:
The condition
:<math>\displaystyle
x^2 < 5
</math>
is equivalent to the conditions
:<math>\displaystyle
- \sqrt{5} < x < \sqrt{5}
</math>

This means, we can rewrite the set ''M'' as being
:<math>\displaystyle
M = \mathbb{Q} \cap (-\sqrt{5},\sqrt{5})
</math>

The infimum of a set being the largest real number that is smaller or equal to all the numbers of the set, it seems to be a good idea to think that -{{sqrt|5}} is a good candidate for the infimum of the set ''M''.

Since -{{sqrt|5}} is clearly smaller than all the numbers of the set ''M'', we only need to show that it is the largest real number with that property.

Assume that there is a number ''m'' with that property as well, that is strictly larger than -{{sqrt|5}}, that is
:<math>
m \leq x \quad\text{for all } x \in M \quad\text{and}\quad m > -\sqrt{5}
</math>
We'll simply show that such a ''m'' cannot exist and hence -{{sqrt|5}} is the infimum of the set ''M''.

Indeed, if ''m'' is strictly larger than -{{sqrt|5}} than it means that the interval
:<math>\displaystyle
(-\sqrt{5} , m)
</math>
is not empty. Since non-empty interval of real numbers contain infinitely many numbers, we can find two distinct numbers in that interval <math>x_1</math> and <math>x_2</math>, that is
:<math>\displaystyle
-\sqrt{5} < x_1 < x_2 < m
</math>

Now a property of the rational numbers is that you can always find a rational number between any two distinct real numbers. That means there must exist a rational number ''q'' between <math>x_1</math> and <math>x_2</math>, so we have
:<math>\displaystyle
-\sqrt{5} < x_1 < q < x_2 < m < \sqrt{5}
</math>
but in particular that means that ''q'' is in the interval (-{{sqrt|5}},{{sqrt|5}}) and since it is rational, ''q'' is an element of the set ''M''. But by construction, ''q'' < ''m'' which contradicts the assumption that ''m'' could be a lower bound of the set ''M''. This means that such a number ''m'' cannot exist and hence the infimum of the set ''M'' has to be -{{sqrt|5}}.
statement_html:
Let M be the set

\[\begin{aligned} M = \{ x \in \mathbb{Q} \mid x^2 < 5 \}\end{aligned}\]

Find, with proof, inf(M).
statement_raw:
Let ''M'' be the set
:<math>M = \{ x \in \mathbb{Q} \mid x^2 < 5 \}</math>
Find, with proof, inf(''M'').
